results.title: Electric Visions
results.brief_description: A teenager at a video parlour plays a new video game. He climbs inside and tests his skills which lead him along the pathway of the development of electricity. Particular reference is made on the role of electricity in the development of Victoria.

results.title: Australian Designers show their talents [excerpt from Australian Diary No. 007]
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
We take a look back at some Australian designs from 1947. Woollen suits, sporty tennis outfits, debutantes gowns, plastic high-heeled shoes! hats and bridal wear are all paraded in this high-end extravaganza of Australian style.
Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection

results.title: Unpacking Filmscapes - The Coloured Sky: New Women II
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Yang Fudong’s five-channel video installation, ‘The Coloured Sky: New Women II’ (2014), marks an aesthetic departure from his signature output on 35mm black and white film to vivid colour.

results.title: Would You Like to Fly?
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and Australia. Dept. of the Interior. Film Division
results.brief_description:
This film was produced by John Kingsford-Smith, nephew of the renowned aviator Charles Kingsford-Smith. John Kingsford-Smith became a successful and prolific producer of documentaries from 1948 to the 1980s. During this time he produced 327 sponsored films and commercials and played a key creative role in all of them (as writer, director, cinematographer or editor).

This film is a combination of his two passions, aviation and filmmaking; one may wonder how many people were spurred on to learn how to fly after watching this film!

results.title: Guide to Canberra
results.creator_credit: Colin Dean and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Produced by the Commonwealth Film Unit in 1958, ‘Guide to Canberra’ was initially intended to inform public servants transferring to Canberra about the lifestyle that they could expect to find in our nation’s growing capital. The glowing report that ensues takes the viewer on a tour of the city’s significant sites, its relaxed shopping districts and new suburban homes, offering a snapshot of Canberra at a time when its population was just 40,000 strong. With its planned transport network, new schools, established retailers and infant café culture, Canberra is depicted as a modern and prosperous city, all the more appealing for the sense of balance afforded by its graceful bushland setting. Whether you view our nation’s capital with affection, indifference or antipathy, this upbeat film leaves little room for doubt that Canberra is unlike any other city in Australia.

results.title: Game Masters: Blizzard Entertainment interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Blizzard Entertainment is a world leading developer and publisher renowned for creating some of the industry’s most critically acclaimed games. Blizzard’s first success was in 1994 with ‘Warcraft: Orcs and Humans’, a game that laid the foundations for the burgeoning real-time strategy genre, introducing gameplay features that would become standards. In 1996 the company released the action-role-playing-game ‘Diablo’. With a track record that includes thirteen number one games and multiple Game of the Year awards, Blizzard Entertainment has gone on to establish one of the largest online followings of any game company worldwide.

The company is best known for the subscription-based massively multiplayer online role-playing games ‘World of Warcraft’ (2004), and ‘StarCraft’ (1998) series. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Fight for Country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: In 1998, over 5,000 people travelled to Kakadu, in the Northern Territory, to stand alongside the traditional owners of the land, the Mirrar people, and lend their support to the Jabiluka Campaign. The fight to prevent the development of the Jabiluka uranium mine was one of the biggest protest movements in Australia’s history and over 600 people were arrested in the process. It took film-maker Pip Starr four years to make this film, including one year spent documenting these historic events.

results.title: Myself When Fourteen
results.creator_credit: Ivor Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Arthur Cantrill
results.brief_description: Brightly coloured animated drawings rotoscoped from high contrast black and white negative film of Ivor Cantrill aged 14, are integrated with the original negative and positive images on an optical printer to create patterns of black, white and colour. The film-maker reminisces about being 14 and describes the rotoscoping process. Ivor Cantrill is autistic, and his attention to detail and his preoccupation with repetition are positive aspects of his condition.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: The Legendary Rex
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Rex Theatre, in Charlton, was built in 1938 and opened with the film ‘Mary, Queen of Scots’. David Pollard, who worked as a projectionist at the theatre since 1980, takes us on a tour of this historic theatre. He is the Chairperson of the Charlton Community Theatre and has been working towards getting The Rex into community ownership, as there is not a large population base for the theatre to be commercially viable.
The community has offered voluntary labour and raised over $80,000 and with the help of fundraising from the federal government, it is hoped the theatre will eventually be completely in the hands of the community.
